com.joffrey_bion.compression.burrows_wheeler

Class BWRotationsMatrix

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.joffrey_bion.compression.burrows_wheeler.BWRotationsMatrix

  •  class BWRotationsMatrix
extends java.lang.Object
    Burrows-Wheeler algorithm requires a conceptual matrix containing all the rotations of the source block to transform. This is what this class represents. All the methods needed by the algorithm to manipulate this matrix are provided here as well. Here is an example of a rotation matrix (for the source text "Brave") before being sorted: 
        0 1 2 3 4
 0  B r a v e
 1  r a v e B 
 2  a v e B r
 3  v e B r a
 4  e B r a v

    Implementation details:

    Representation of the rotations: Storing all rotations as Strings or as a matrix of Characters would be a total waste of space since the rotations of the source block contain the exact same characters. Therefore, the source block is stored only once (as the original String), and each rotation is represented by an integer defined as follows: the rotation i is obtained by rotating the source block i times to the left (or i characters to the left). For instance, "lloHe" is the rotation 2 of "Hello", and the source block is always the rotation 0.

    Representation of the matrix: The matrix can then be represented by an array of integer, whose indices are the rows of the matrix, and whose values are the rotation number (that we have just defined) corresponding to each row. For example, here is the matrix that we have seen for the source "Brave" (before sorting): 

     Brave (i=0, source block)
 raveB (i=1)
 aveBr (i=2)
 veBra (i=3)
 eBrav (i=4)
    This matrix would be represented by the following array : {0, 1, 2, 3, 4}. Indeed, for all i, the rotation i is at row i of the matrix. And after being lexicographically sorted: 
     aveBr (i=2)
 Brave (i=0, source block)
 eBrav (i=4)
 raveB (i=1)
 veBra (i=3)
    This matrix would now be represented by the following array : {2, 0, 4, 1, 3}.

    Author:
    Joffrey Bion
